headline: Avoid
pros:
Beautiful NY office.
Flexible work from home policy.
Small company, hard work will get you noticed.
cons:
Senior management too focused on hiring in low cost countries to fill gaps. 
Current analysts are overloaded causing them to flee this company.
Operations are much more complicated then they have to be and can be very frustrating.

headline: PineBridge
pros: Very personal environment with a new headquarters in NYC. Global presence is strong. Product line up is Fixed Income heavy; the Alternatives business is growing.
cons: Financially very tight on expense spend.

headline: Great team
pros: Gives a lot of support
cons: Not much growth in career path

headline: n/a
pros: people, working hours, social events
cons: alot of change within the management team

headline: Not bad
pros: People, Benefits and Market Salaries
cons: Most are stretched thin and majority of managers need management training

headline: Nice place to work
pros: flexible work from home policy
cons: lack of benefits and employee education

headline: Great place to work
pros: Multiple opportunities to learn and grow, great colleagues and friendly environment
cons: I did not see any cons till day if my redundancy

headline: Hong Kong office
pros:
interesting work
culture is not bad
cons:
High turnover and not being able to keep the talents
Very local culture/no diversity

headline: Firm lacks direction, competitive edge, process orientation, and visionary leadership
pros: Flat organization allows for career growth for strong performers
cons:
Product is not competitive in the marketplace, scattershot approach to fundraising

Organization has lost edge as the marketplace moves ever-increasingly toward complex product structures

Almost every team across the firm (except for a few under strong leadership) lacks process, and an insufficient bench of strong junior talent results in limited bandwidth to create / implement process

Bad apples make it a frustrating place to work for strong performers

headline: Good work life balance
pros: Great team, good emphasis on employees development and career plan
cons: Not much to say about this

headline: Great place to work
pros: Collaborative environment where those looking to achive can make a name for themselve regardless of level.
cons: Stale outdated processes need reassessing.

headline: Nice working environment
pros: Cooperative and helpful colleagues; nice working environment
cons: Do not think there is clear business direction from senior management

headline: Great Experience
pros: Mobility, close-knit culture, flexible work arrangements
cons: Sometimes tasks can be manual as opposed to automated.

headline: Entrepreneurial, but can lead to burn out
pros: Small teams, lots of visibility, wear different hats
cons: Under-resourced, managing work-life balance can be tough

headline: great place to start career
pros: great place to start career
cons: different product and strategy focus

headline: pretty good
pros: comps fair, they don't micro manage. smart investment teams.
cons: products aren't positioned for today and the future

headline: Great place to work
pros: There’s great Diversity within the group
cons: Can be Long hours at times

headline: gd
pros: pay, bonus, peoples, job, environment
cons: working hr, hireachy, training etc

headline: Great place to work
pros: The firm has a great culture and is always striving to be better.
cons: Some roles/departments carry a lot of responsibility that needs to be better deployed across the firm and to the relevant departments. Though, big changes with streamlining and efforts to do this.

headline: Bureaucracy
pros: Stable environment that offer reasonable comps.
cons: Bureaucratic and senior management slow to react to market conditions

headline: Good company overall.
pros: Decent compensation and employee friendly.
cons: Nothing as such that is bothersome.

headline: Growing Mnc
pros: Very good working environment and supportive management
cons: Good work life balance and no cons

headline: Great place
pros: Incredible people, strong culture, good worklife balance
cons: Pay is very below industry

headline: Great place to work
pros: Collaborative environment, clear channels of communication, effective leadership, very focused on D&I.
cons: None, absolutely a delight to be associated with PineBridge Investments.

headline: Great Company
pros: Flat organization. Accepting culture. Able to rise through the ranks.
cons: Compensation could be higher vs. comparable firms.

headline: Product Development
pros: Proactive Teamwork and Strategic Brainstorming
cons: Too fast to smooth the process

headline: NAA
pros: Asia focused and growing company
cons: Brand recognition is still lacking

headline: Work Life
pros: Good work life balance at the firm
cons: Management and economics could be better

headline: Good
pros: Good mix and professional team, Transparency
cons: slightly unhealthy work-life balance overall

headline: Culture has improved
pros: PineBridge has materially improved in terms of a progressive and nimble culture from its AIG origins. The improvements have come from the current CEO, leadership team, and the employees themselves.
cons: It is not clear if overall profitability of the firm is at a sustainable level.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Lean teams with lots of autonomy to operate and make a meaningful impact
cons: Occasionally feel like too much freedom - more structured training programs for new hires would be appreciated

headline: Great colleagues to work with
pros: The people at the office were all very intellectual, had a culture that prided in being nimble to capture market opportunities
cons: Sometimes felt like no room for career progression due to smaller scale offices

headline: Analyst
pros: Best salary good worklife balance
cons: No cons all good work culture

headline: Good place for career progression
pros: Strong growth outlook. Solid Team and good working relationships.
cons: Intense work environment. Could have better work life balance

headline: Great company
pros: The great management team and working environment
cons: Less flexibility on the promotion

headline: Great work life balance.
pros: Great work life balance, nice people. The invest in people training.
cons: No cons as such. All is well

headline: Director
pros: Great culture, great location, great teams
cons: Perks, strict timings, no remote working

headline: Product Development
pros: Quite flexible, good chance to get in touch with many different products and projects.
cons: Not systematic, sometimes can be chaos, may need to work for long hours

headline: Associate
pros:
- Good Compensation
- A chance to get a lot of responsibility since the beginning
- Work-life balance
cons: - Some processes occasionally too bureaucratic

headline: intern
pros: Great team, fast paced environment
cons: nothing, I find it is a great fit for myself

headline: Constantly Losing AUM
pros:
- Somewhat lax environment relative to a Blackstone or some other top tier asset management firm
- $80 billion asset manager so it looks good on your resume and you could finesse that into a better paying job at another firm
cons:
- Losing AUM which means less money for the firm which means less money in the form of bonuses and raises for employees whether they're a top performer or not or whether their particular business line made money. Raises and bonuses for people who got promoted were not good.
- constantly trying to create new products to keep up with the runoff on AUM
- heard from multiple people that they were incentivized to inflate AUM figures
- name of the game is to maintain AUM even if it's not financially viable so products are offered with rock bottom fee structures only for investors to redeem a few months later

headline: Senior Associate
pros: Not that I am aware of.
cons: Poor coordination between teams.  Poor leadership by the Asia ex JP CEO who is not really a leader.  Imagine a region CEO staying in a firm for more than 20 years as a legacy from the AIA age who has failed to develop real business except for passive inflow.  While the mutual fund market is under speedy development and restructuring worldwide , PineBridge's way of doing business remains at the stone age.

headline: Vice President
pros: Global platform with well diversified
cons: Care more about earning than clients

headline: Middle Office Associate
pros: Nice people. Majority friendly and willing to help. Good benefits, 401K.
cons: Little room for career advancement and development. A lot of the day to day is the same. Sub par bonus pay for the work load and raises very infrequent even to hard workers.

headline: Diversity
pros: Diversity is encouraged, you can wear many hats, opportunity to learn. Daily contact with colleagues in different regions.
cons: No resources allocated to technology, a lot of manual processes can be improved to streamline and create economies of scale.

headline: A demanding but very good firm with upside potential
pros: Generally nice people  Opportunity for learning and professional development  Much focus on marketing  Management seems willing to promote from within those who deliver results Good work-life balance
cons: Pay is not competitive but given low assets per employee is not a surprise  The firm is overstaffed

headline: "Great experience"
pros: -Really great working environment in my opinion
cons: -Can't really come up with any

headline: Compliance officer
pros: There is work life balance, off around 7pm
cons: Local culture and mean boss... heavy workload, being monitored always, very politics

headline: A great place to work
pros:
The people are intelligent, friendly and there is a sense of community and a positive culture. 

The company is growing and there is a sense that with the new(ish) CEO and PineBridge have a clear strategy that is being delivering on.

The company is big enough that it is a truly global organisation, but small enough that you get to know a lot of people personally (and from experience, the vast majority are a pleasure to deal with).

Employees do a lot of activities and fundraising for charity.
cons: There has been a lot of change in senior management but this has stabilised.

headline: Great Place to Make an Impact
pros: Great place to work if you like to chart your own course, are not afraid to take ownership, take on new challenges, and get things done.  Nice people and a flexible work environment.
cons: Don’t expect too much in terms of infrastructure or process.

headline: A friendly and collegiate place to work
pros: The people are generally first class - friendly and highly collaborative. The company is entrepreneurial and growing quickly.
cons: Not many if you turn up prepared to work hard and get stuck in.

headline: No Hard Work Recognition
pros: You won't get fired unless you do something too crazy to hurt their business.
cons: Mangers don't care about about employees, no incentive , no reward . Terrible for career beginners

headline: Summer internship
pros: Great people, great communication between departments
cons: Nothing bad to say at all

headline: Worse than a tire fire!
pros: Still some nice people left.
cons:
Firm is run by a bunch of hooligans masquerading as a leadership team,  Most aren't qualified to run their own department let alone a rapidly failing firm.

Morale is at an all-time low.  The smart people are leaving left and right because they're overworked due to high turnover,  underpaid and stifled by incompetent managers. Career growth is non-existent.  Unqualified people are overpromoted to keep them at the firm because these poor managers can't do the work of their subordinates (they just take the credit for it).  Support employees are treated like second class citizens.  Those in investments reap all the benefits.  The firm bleeds money but it can somehow fly investment employees all around the world for a special conference and wine and dine leadership.  What about the rest of us? We're all sitting here waiting for the next layoff and wondering who will be canned next.

To add to an already horrid work environment, the latest regime took away all that was good about the firm - Summer Fridays, monthly happy hours, summer party, etc.  You're basically punished for sticking around.  Next, we'll be celebrating our holiday party in the conference room.

headline: Intern
pros: Very welcoming colleagues, good working environment
cons: No cons, greatly enjoyed my time here

headline: Up and coming company with close-knit enviroment
pros: Pinebridge is a good company to join with a close-knit team in London. It is one of the more truly global companies - in part due to the fact it is smaller so needs to be more integrated. There is not much politics to deal with, and the corporate environment is quite positive.
cons: The work-life balance is not great, in part due to the international nature of the firm - you may end up doing long and strange hours. Due to its small nature management can be quite hands-off - you have to be able to work well with a reduced amount of supervision!

headline: Managing Director
pros:
- Still a great platform with a US base and international network
- Scale assets under management
cons:
- Decaying intellectual capital
- Ownership shifting from AIG to an Asian family owned platform changed the risk perception in the eyes of the Limited Partners, hence, the firm is losing its attractiveness for U.S. institutional platforms because it is loosing its old established  values of doing business

headline: Awful
pros:
Since the formation of PineBridge in 2010 from AIG, the company has done very well, mainly due to some excellent PMs producing top quartile performances across a number of years and over numerous strategies. The working environment is relaxed and I actually have no complaints in general about the quality of staff. My colleagues were mainly very friendly and good to work with. 

Work/life balance was decent. 

The new CEO seemed to be very good.
cons:
The senior 'management' at the London office are a joke. Please note, I refer to two individuals mainly (one of whom recently announced his resignation) but within certain teams, the same can be said. Never before have a group of such under qualified, inexperienced, egotistical, autocratic, selfish and untrustworthy people been allowed to run a business. Their concerns are only for themselves and the amount of money they make (which is ludicrous) so do not join this firm thinking anybody has got your back. 

My advice would be to think carefully about joining this company. If you are prepared to get on the right side of the boss and play the very political game that is required then do it well otherwise they will have no hesitation at all in getting rid of you with the ruthless culture that is embedded within the firm. 

It took me moving to another, much more progressive and open asset management firm to realise that the culture at PineBridge is toxic.

headline: Decent
pros: Try to do the things bigger investment companies do with perks, bonuses etc
cons: Senior management needed to be overhauled

headline: Assistant
pros: Multicultural environment, friendly and professional team
cons: I do not see any negative aspects of this job

headline: Pros and cons
pros:
A good place for retirees or losers from big fund house to find a second career here.
Work/life balance for senior executives
cons:
The experience here cannot add too much value to your CV.
Lack of resources and uneven resource allocations.
Lack of training opportunities.
No synchronized actions or focus products for each offices.
Highly political and under the table factional fighting

headline: NEVER WORK HERE
pros: The only pro is that you can maintain a good lifestyle balance.
cons: Each group operates in its own silo with no incentive or culture to cross-sell and unify as a whole.  Not much opportunity for upward mobility; instead many of the group heads like to hinder progress or help each member drive towards excellence.  Title and compensation structure is not aligned to industry standards

headline: Start up office
pros: Great exposure in one of the firm's start up office in a developing market, great for entry level employees to quickly experience different aspects of investment job
cons: Questionable local leadership without clear direction in start up office, lacks clear path to future nor structured approach for daily operations

headline: Full time
pros: Great People to work with!
cons: few advancement opportunity, hard to be promoted

headline: Don't waste your time
pros: Independent asset manager with a shot at growth, but the team has to be encouraged to work together and incentives should be aligned. . . Finally
cons: Too political, too many secrets and promotions seem aimed very low, to shine at the top by comparison. Favoritism, silos, this is the kind of work environment for you?

headline: operations
pros: Great People, Good location, perks
cons: Poor wages, to much management

headline: On the up
pros: Increasingly building up great talents, collaborative culture
cons: lack infrastructure to accommodate business growth

headline: Positive
pros: The people that work at the office are nice.  Managers communicate clearly and give feedback about assignments after you hand them in.  Great place to work, learn, grow.
cons: Workload can vary immensely.  Sometimes, there is very little/nothing to do for long periods of time, whereas other weeks may have you staying late 5 days a week.

headline: Going in the right direction
pros: Great place to work with good life balance
cons: Some transition issues but are getting worked out

headline: VP
pros:
New CEO really making a difference.  Dynamic.  Focused.  Open.
Winning big new mandates in institutional.  And awards for performance.  Are we reaching a "sweet spot"? .  Good time to join.
cons:
Tough coming out of period of uncertainty.
Tight cost controls can be frustrating.

headline: Review
pros: Great people. Very small office so you feel comfortable very early on. Great office culture as well.
cons: I was not really there long enough to realize any major issues that needed solving.

headline: Dreadful place to work
pros: In amongst all the corporate politics there were some very nice people working there
cons: Poorly managed through the transition from AIG, everybody just in it for themselves. Non-existent communication left a void which was filled with speculation about the future and whether your team was part of it, rife politics. Everybody was unhappy.

headline: Promising, but lacking
pros: The people are for the most part very friendly and bright. The firm seems to be gaining ground in the industry.
cons: Not enough communication between departments when the whole firm sits on the same floor. Investments in current people and processes are not a priority.

headline: Not a ship to sail on for long
pros: Not many almost to the point of disinterest from senior management.
cons:
They took over AIG Investments and started job cuts almost immediately. I was not laid off since I was in an essential role. However I relocated to another country, one they had a big presence in and on writing to the HR it was a cold response.
String of senior management exits.

headline: Need to hire experience team heads in Asia Regional Office
pros: Good $$$$$$. Be prepared to work long hours due to incompetent bosses.
cons: The HoDs in Hong Kong have no extensive experience in asset management prior to joining PineBridge. PB is like a learning ground to most of them. These people love to  fabricate tales to Head Office in New York. Agreed with the statement "Blinded people leading the Bright people"

headline: Blind leading bright people leads to bright people blinded
pros: - lots of opportunities to perform as some team heads don't know what they are doing
cons:
- team head surrounding themselves with yes men and promotion goes to not to people who perform but people who agree 
- divisional team heads give all excuses not to actively look for clients so they needn't do the work yet taking credit for their reporting staff's hard work means diligent, intelligent employees who come up with bright ideas and question integrity issues get disgruntled and leave 
- country CEO don't bother as they cloud information of real situation and keep the useless 'yes' heads around to hide the problem

headline: Stable company with an awesome culture and an exciting future!
pros: Having worked at large, stuffy investment banks in the past, I love everything that PineBridge has to offer! It's a mid-sized buy side firm with stability and a huge growth potential. The investing culture isn't risky yet very thoughtful. The people culture is amazing. Everyone works hard yet knows how to have fun. There are fun events like monthly happy hours, summer parties, holiday parties to allow employees to engage and connect with one another. Because the company is lean, it allows employees to be autonomous in their role and implement change if there's a need. The company environment definitely allows work life balance but like any other firm, if there is busy season in the area that you work in, extended work hours are required.
cons: While we had the interim CEO, I felt the company was at a standstill. Recently, the Firm appointed a new CEO! I'm excited to see the valuable changes he'll make for PineBridge.

headline: No growth and no prospect
pros: Flexible hours. Management don't keep track of staff not working or not in office. No practical growth strategy and there is no practical idea where or how or what the firm is heading. Small funds would be kept even if they are unprofitable as the firm lacks any other products.
cons: Staff departures are frequent events in PineBridge. Management will guide in town halls with "ambitious" growth plans, but the firm is basically staying the same with no growth after years. In fact, it is cutting people and offices. Lack of products and AUM as comparing to most other asset management firms. Only a few clients for the whole firm as there are many structural issues that clients would normally avoid.

headline: PineBridge Inter
pros: Constructive learning environment and helpful analyst/associates.
cons: Work can become repetitive at times.

headline: Former employee
pros: Decent place to work.   Nice, smart people
cons: Organization is undergoing restructuring in some parts of its business

headline: No growth, holding pattern
pros: Increasing responsibility and opportunity to learn from senior managers
cons: No CEO! No direction, and losing assets

headline: No Leadership, No Growth
pros: Great work/life balance if you're in upper management. Perks like summer outings and monthly social events keep things interesting and the culture is generally safe and positive for women, LGBTQ, and religious/racial/ethnic minorities. Up to a match of 5% on 401(k) contributions.
cons: PineBridge has been adrift and without a CEO since March of this year, making it impossible for the company to commit to any outlook or growth strategy. Much worse, however, is the firm's failure to implement decisions made prior to the CEO's departure. Management is increasingly "too busy" to speak with staff, which (among other things) has morale at an all-time low. Everyone has been in a holding pattern for two quarters, going on three. At year-end, we fully expect low or no raises and small bonuses due to the company's lack of growth. That's not how you reward loyalty.

headline: Business Development
pros: There are some good people, who know their job and are easy to get along with
cons: Lack of direction and no understanding of who they are

headline: Quality of staff in general is sub-par.
pros: Decent comp, good benefits, not too bad good work/life balance.
cons: Lots of 'long serving' incompetent and lazy staff. PM still stuck with old mentality of portfolio management. Mediocre performance at best. Not many people in the office to look up to as top talent will not join this form.

headline: md
pros: flexibility - you can come and go as you please and no one is watching. You can miss work or work from home.
cons: no direction - although it seems to be getting better now with the departure of the old ceo...problem is that its a family owned firm and there is no accountability

headline: Back office staff in Hong Kong
pros:
- Good starting salary
- Colleagues are nice in general
cons:
- No career development
- Hard working staff not being rewarded
- Managers backstabbing own team members is a common thing

headline: Great Company to work for with very good benefits.
pros: The Los Angeles Leveraged Loan Team is the best group I have worked for. They are professional, caring and hardworking.
cons: The Company should recognize the dedication of its employees with an annual salary increase even if it’s not of great significance.

headline: Stay Away
pros:
-Compensation is competitive
-Nice office space
cons:
I am an ex-employee, but I am trying to be objective.  In a little over a years time at Pinebridge the company laid off almost 30% of its employees.  You can reduce employees and expenses as much as you want but if you don't increase sales you will not be profitable.
-No clear communication form either senior or middle management.
-Work/Life balance is horrible.
-Backstabbing culture.

headline: Good company to work for but long hours and hardly any breaks.
pros: The pay varies could be higher for the long hours of work. People are nice and professional.
cons: Their hours are 9-5 but it's really working through your lunch and after hours.  Since its a global company you also work on your vacation, sick and personal days via your BlackBerry, Ipad or computer.  The workload is very demanding and time sensitive.  Hardly time for breaks or lunch.

headline: Tough transition
pros: Lots of opportunity get senior roles
cons: Tons of politics and no clear direction

headline: Great Experience Great Culture
pros: Wonderful and motivated Leadership and investment team. The all hands on deck approach is one that really appealed to me about my time at PineBridge. Entrepreneurial spirit of the company is very rewarding
cons: Work/Life Balance suffers, a lot of work and not enough hours, If not managed properly could burn out even the best employees.

headline: Toxic work culture
pros: decent office space located in heart of midtown manhattan financial district. they have a global presence with offices on a few continents. people are mostly nice.
cons: slow bleed layoffs led to toxic work culture which lacked trust and resulted in coworkers backstabbing each other.

headline: No clear direction from management
pros:
It used to be a great company with a good corporate culture. 
Great investment platform for an asset manager.
cons: Since the separation from AIG the management and ownership struggles to position clearly  the firm.

headline: Excellent firm
pros: Excellent firm and great to work
cons: I have no cons at this time

headline: Lack of work-life balance, long hours and unhappy employees.
pros: Generally the employees were down to earth and approachable. The benefits were ok, but could be better. Cost cutting has had an adverse effect.
cons: Lack of leadership was always a constant challenge. The slave driving nature of the business at PineBridge created a very negative atmosphere. People sees me to be always looking for a way out.

headline: A great company to work for
pros: I have been with this company for 9 years and every year has been more rewarding than the last. I have had a wonderful team of professionals guide me and encourage me in my personal and professional development. The culture around the organization has changed for the positive and I would say the change has been driven by a management that really listens to and cares about their employees. There are really exciting opportunities to be had as a PineBridge employee.
cons: There is a lot of work to do and there is never any downtime. But it is great to be part of a team that is working tirelessly towards growing PineBridge Investments.

headline: PineBridge is a great employer!
pros: Great people and strong management team.  PineBridge management has made great strides in turning things around and has done an excellent job developing the next generation of talent.  Employees are collaborative and we are encouraged to share our ideas in order to continuously improve and create new efficiencies.  I am proud to be part of the PineBridge team.
cons: There is work to be done in improving work-life balance.  PineBridge has made significant progress in this area and is moving in the right direction.

headline: Hopeful company
pros: Good attitude among staff, friendly environment.
cons: Sketchy management styles - people in roles they're not qualified for.

headline: Great firm, great people...
pros: I truly enjoy coming to work every day and interacting with some of the best and brightest in the business.  Although we work hard, we have fun along the way.  It's unique to be in an environment where employees are recognized for their contributions and senior management listens to employees at all levels about how to make this the best place to work.
cons: Lots of work to do, but it keeps it challenging!

headline: Eliminating the negative
pros: Flexible work schedules, visible/approachable senior management team, great people, opportunities for growth and development, hard work does not go unnoticed and collaborative work environment.
cons:
- Internal politics slow down the decision making process
- Some of senior management's direct reports are not timely in communicating important information/changes with their teams
- Certain teams do not consider project deadlines and consistently deliver content at the 11th hour (there are no enforced consequences for missing deadlines)

headline: Getting a lot better...
pros: Good group of people. Great work/life balance. Looks like senior management cares.
cons: A lot of managers don't know how to manage or communicate.

headline: Hidden Gem
pros: Great open and inclusive culture, work/life balance, community involvement, better transparency from management and employees.
cons: Old habits of employees who have been through the firm's transition - still hold on to old culture

headline: Decent, Laid Back, Nice people
pros: Laid back as it used to be a part of AIG
cons: Too laid back, no sense of urgency

headline: It was fine
pros: People are friendly, some managers have open door policy.
cons:
Terrible temps were often hired
Large disparage in salaries

headline: Decent pay but unfriendly and highly political environment.
pros: The pay is decent, especially at the intern level. Nice office and great midtown location. Large Asset Manager handling large amounts of money.
cons: Highly political, lack of communication between senior management and the rest of the firm. Departments are highly insular and there is little to no interaction between employees in different groups.

headline: Going through significant changes
pros: Nice people to work with
cons: Lots of change, makes for a difficult environment

headline: Short, Terse, and Learning Experience
pros:
-Small/Mid Size company
-Clean working environment
cons: -Too many managers not enough work horses

headline: They have turned their brand around, it is a compelling proposition. Could be a winner.  Some teams outperformed in 2012
pros: Support teams outperformed, Legal, Comms, HR, and Product Mngmnt helped bring professionalism in 2012. Great working environment for young experienced professionals. Sarting to feel like a smart place.
cons: Low staff for all there is to do. Need to spend to get awareness of the corporate brand story. Need stonger marketing, quality is not consistent. Big picture is going in the right direction, details need attention.

headline: Great people working hard and having fun in a relaxed environment.
pros: The LA office is relaxed, friendly, and supportive, the benefits are very good, and you are valued as an individual.  Turnover is very low, which points to the fact that most people like working there.  The California culture, which makes the LA office a great place to work, does not extend to the rest of the company.  Employees visiting from other cities often comment on how different the LA office is: no office politics, no surreptitious positioning, and no cutthroat hijinks.
cons: Because of the low turnover, training receives very little attention, and the pay could be better.

headline: Room for improvement
pros: global connections, good opportunity if they can make it work
cons: not very client focused; not very employee focused;  New York centric

headline: Management not focused on keeping talent
pros: Lots of freedom to take on responsibilities as resource is scarce
cons: Management committees are formed with senior people who do not know much but talk alot.  Selection into committees are very much based on favoritism, not on quality hence company is led by very poor managers with only short term targets.  Dissenting comments are not welcomed.  VPs and MDs are not treated equally and favoritism abounds.  Experienced senior people leaving.  Very little focus on career building as heads of departments are more concerned on keeping their own jobs and hence surround themselves with 'yes men'.

headline: Entrepreneurial and Professional environment
pros:
-Great Colleagues and knowledge sharing
-New initiatives focused on the employees' growth and development
-Senior managements new approach to the strategic direction of the firm, building our culture and transparency
cons: Lack of resources in some areas

headline: Undergoing structural change
pros:
- Lots of different asset classes
- Good People to work with
cons:
- Slow to evolve, business lacked strategy now has one which may or may not be successful
- 100% change of senior management and significant global headcount reduction has created uncertainty
- Below market compensation

headline: The place where hope went to die.............
pros: For a long while it felt like a family, all working together towards a common goal.  The future looked bright, and then one day it just didn't anymore.
cons: No loyalty, no communication, no vision for the future, or if there is one, it is never shared. Things changed rapidly during 2012, and not in a good way.

headline: Sinking Ship
pros:
easy place to pass the time until job market gets better
compensation is fantastic for a few select individuals but horrible for the rest
cons:
senior management is distant and has no idea how to run an investment management firm
complete turnover on senior level from AIG days - old guys were bad but new team is 100X worse
new ceo was brought on that has no experience with this type of asset manager
absentee owner pits senior managers against each other

headline: Only time will tell...
pros: Great place to learn and be exposed to the complexities of growing a business.
cons: Pay, openness, commitment to a single idea / philosophy.

headline: Good learning experience but compensation lags market
pros: good learning experience. Plently of work since resources are limited and dont get replaced when people depart. Good for someone who is young.
cons: Poor compensation and senior management does not know what they are doing. Staff morale is low in general. Prospects for advancement limited.

headline: Relaxed Work Environment, Lack of Senior Leadership
pros: Relaxed/comfortable work environment with decent benefits.
cons: A large number of current senior and junior staff are just "hanging out" until a better job offer comes along.  Compensation is middle of the road.  Lack of senior leadership or firm direction, particularly from a sales perspective.  Too diversified from a product perspective.  Slow erosion of AUM due to weak portfolio management oversight at the senior level.

headline: can't see the light at the end of the tunnel
pros: great colleagues; job security; ok pay
cons: management has no managerial/leadership skills; moving within departments is not supported; lots of favoritism; lack of resources

headline: Growing pains in a tough market
pros: Great people in my department.  The team is extremely supportive of each other and we realize the importance of our role supporting the business.  Individuals are eager to lend a hand if they have expertise and bandwidth.
cons: New (ish) business struggling to do the things it did under a larger better resourced parent company.  Scalability of operations and ambition appears to be quite a challenge in a tight market. Businesses competing for scarce resources as "Individuals." Poor focus on strategic or product prioritization.
